body:
There are so many ways to wince, so varied the gradients of wincing, so vast the symbolism captured, of nuance and feeling and intellect and zest. Or life, or something like that. Some thing like that. Some thing like a wince.

There is the pain wince, the sheepish caught out wince, the bad comedian syndrome - vicarious embarrassment wince, the angry wince, the wince of the slap of surprise. Perhaps never before, never before now, never before the weird public-private mirror-non-mirror display that is the conversation we have with our cell phones, never before this digital communications moment has the wince been so meaningful, so elaborate and delicate and underappreciated. The wince of excited apology at the thought of the inherent illicitness of the exclusiveness of this ever so personal vibration reaching in to you from inside your own pocket. The secret-up-to-you-to-tell or notice that someone wants you, no matter how banal your moment. The guilty pleasure of alone-smiling, wide-grinning at an interactive screen activated just for… for me? For me! Like a wacko in love. Or something. Some thing.

Bill pulls his phone out of his pocket. The thing was, the thing is, Erin and he share not just a number of deep understandings and true levels of friendship but they, they, they? They also share a non-routine. That quiet coordination of activity that can occur between people who understand they live in a world that is not ever going to change to understand them back. The working within and also between the watery crack spots. The not-resigned acceptance of non-acceptance that shimmies and shines without ever taking any notice. Like the space between rocks and the brief flows of wet during rain. And equally predictable down to half a second and without technology. As in, not predictable at all. Their passion depends on that. They make a need, they have, over years, forged a need out of not needing each other. They can both depend and up end it, simultaneously. It is rare and inevitable.

Bill keeps a camper at the campground. He inherited it from an uncle. He inherited it twenty-two years ago, when he was fifteen and it was eleven years old. He’s repaired the floor boards, though, repeatedly. And he keeps two fresh buckets of Be-Dri (one in the cabinet, one underneath) on the premises at all times. He keeps fresh sheets in a sealed and ventilated cedar closet he made from an old refrigerator, towels, too. He washes them in coin-op machines at the shower house, a ten-minute walk away through thick woods. They closed this cul-de-sac to regular campers almost ten years ago. But seeing as how Bill’s camper was no longer fit to move, they let him stay while the forest grew back in close around him. He would never say so out loud to himself but he felt that the coincidental privacy was… was somehow meant for him. For him and Erin.

His place is no secret, that’s for sure. He keeps the road back to his area clear himself, and local regulars are known to sit around the fire ring in his “yard” on the weekends. But during the week and for the most part, Bill finds peace and quiet here any time he likes. Neither Erin, nor anyone else for that matter, has ever interrupted him at his camper, uninvited.

Bill looks at his phone screen and winces. A wince chock full of complex contradictions. It is Friday, there is a good chance Cherrie will go to her sister’s for the evening. He types: 75% chance at the campground tonight.

Erin replies: I’ll be there. Cousins in town, it will be wild but… i’ll keep my fingers crossed for goodnights.
